results.title: [Compilation. No. 01]
results.brief_description: A compilation of three short silent films featuring newsreel footage on the following: 1. Charles Lindbergh’s triumphant public receptions after his Transatlantic flight - in Paris, Brussels, London, Washington DC and New York. Presentation by President Coolidge of Distinguished Flying Cross (Kinnogram Films). 2. Footage of koalas with explanatory intertitles (Kodak Australia). 3. Footage of kangaroos, wallabies, bandicoots etc with explanatory intertitles (Development and Migration Commission).

results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board
results.brief_description: Using archival stills and prints, and aerial shots the film traces the Yarra River from its source in the Great Dividing Range to its entry into Port Phillip Bay, emphasising its importance as a natural asset. Also shows geographical features such as the delta from Princes Bridge, Melbourne to Fisherman’s Bend, the port complex and various sporting facilities. Discusses the planning policy for the Yarra Valley prepared by the Town and Country Planning Board, Victoria’s state planning authority. “Modern man causes problems to this priceless asset” (Liberal Minister Dick Hamer).

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing

results.title: Weevils mean business
results.creator_credit: AWB Limited and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The problem of weevil infestation in bulk wheat storage and its control in Australia. Weevils and other insect pests in grain are a potential danger to the well-being of Australian wheatgrowers. Shows the Board’s suggested methods of insect control on the farm and traces the story of Australian wheat from the farm to its consumption overseas.

results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Television and United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.

results.title: Mining men
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia
results.brief_description: Describes the opportunities available for young men in the mining industry. It outlines the work of the graduate geologist, the mining engineer, the metallurgist and others and gives a comprehensive picture of life and work in new and developing mining communities of Australia.

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Remix: The Races]
results.creator_credit: Dakota Henderson, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This short remix of films about horse racing set to music, takes you through from getting ready and arriving at the track, to placing a bet, the race and the result.

This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to some of the activities around the spring racing carnival that takes place in Melbourne during October and November. It captures the race preparations for both people and horses, and shows the mounting yard, the TAB bets, the race call and a punter finding out the winner.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge donor: Ivan Gaal ( Dir., ‘The Punter’, 1978).

results.title: My family
results.brief_description:
After a divorce Nga decides to start life again and migrate to Australia. She reflects on how difficult it is to raise her children alone and how sad she was that she could not afford to give them much and had to work long hours. Nga has come to terms with her guilt and grief when she shares in the successes of her children.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.
